title: Is there common law marriage in CA?
question: The mother of my child and I have been together for 11 years, now she wants to separate. She has not worked in 8 of those years. First is she my wife? Second, is she entitled to alimony or any of my assets? I realize that I will have to pay child support and how would that be calculated?
question_tags: Child support,Alimony,Child custody,Bankruptcy,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and alimony,Bankruptcy and debt,Child support and custody,Paternity and child custody,Family law,Paternity,Domestic relationships,Marriage,Common-law marriage
answers:
There is no common law marriage in California. If you did reside in a state that recognized common law marriage and you resided there long enough to established a common law marriage in that state then California would recognize the marriage.
The court will not award spousal support unless you were married. The court also has no jurisdiction to divide and property.
While Palimony may be an issue under the Marvin case it is difficult to prove.
A Paternity action would need to be filed to determine child custody and visitation as well as child support. It is possible if the Department of Child Support Services gets involved to establish a child support order without any custody or visitation orders.
You should seriously consult with a family law attorney to discuss your options and make sure you are an active part of your children's lives.
